testsuite.system-out: Let's solve this as an equation then round appropriately. \begin{align*} S_n&=\dfrac{a(r^{n-1})}{r-1}\text{, where }r=6\div2=3\text{ and }a=2.\\ 1000&=\dfrac{2(3^{n-1})}{3-1}\\ 1000\times2&=2(3^{n-1})\\ 2000&=2(3^{n-1})\\ 1000&=3^{n-1}\\ \ln1000&=\ln(3^{n-1})\\ \ln1000&=(n-1)\ln3\\ n-1&=\dfrac{\ln1000}{\ln3}\\ n&=\dfrac{\ln1000}{\ln3}+1\\ &=7.29... \end{align*} Therefore $8$ terms are needed. 8 Let $2,6,18$ be the first three terms of a geometric sequence. How many terms are needed for the sum to first exceed $1000$?
